title: Getting Started
text: Data source: ?mgcv::predict.gam First, fit simple GAM model.
code: library("oddsratio")  fit_gam <- mgcv::gam(y ~ s(x0) + s(I(x1^2)) + s(x2) + offset(x3) + x4,   data = data_gam )

what: Calculating Odds Ratio for Static Increases of a Continuous Variable
title: Getting Started
text: example take predictor x2 (randomly chosen). First define start stop values via values. Inspecting plot see odds response y happening 22 times higher predictor x2 increases 0.099 0.198, holding predictors constant. detailed steps Set predictors mean value Predict response, Change selected predictor new value predict response . result two “log odds” values, subsequently transformed “odds”. Finally, odds ratio can calculated two odds values.
code: or_gam(   data = data_gam, model = fit_gam, pred = "x2",   values = c(0.099, 0.198) ) #>   predictor value1 value2 oddsratio CI_low (2.5%) CI_high (97.5%) #> 1        x2  0.099  0.198  23.32353      23.30424        23.34283

title: Getting Started
text: or_gam() able handle factor variables. levels compared need passed values. , change odds y happening predictor x4 changing level B rather small: increase odds 37.8% can observed.
code: or_gam(   data = data_gam, model = fit_gam,   pred = "x4", values = c("A", "B") ) #>   predictor value1 value2 oddsratio CI_low (2.5%) CI_high (97.5%) #> 1        x4      A      B  1.377537      1.334837        1.421604

what: Odds ratio for Percentage increases of a Continuous Variables
title: Getting Started
text: get impression odds ratio changes throughout complete range smoothing function fitted GAM model specific predictor, odds ratios based percentage steps predictors distribution. slice predictor x2 five parts extracting predictor values 20% steps. can see high odds ratio reported increasing predictor x2 0.008 0.206 predictor increases decrease odds response y happening substantially.

title: Getting Started
text: plot_gam() helps simplify plotting GAM smoothing functions R:  can customize look using colors line types. Besides making use implemented arguments function, can save result plot_gam() object add ggplot2 calls afterwards.
code: library(ggplot2) plot_gam(fit_gam, pred = "x2", title = "Predictor 'x2'") +   theme_minimal()

what: Add Odds Ratio Information Into Smoothing Function Plot
title: Getting Started
text: far computed odds ratios created plot GAM smoothing function. combine ? insert_or()aims . takes ggplot plotting object containing smooth function [data.frame] returned or_gam() containing information predictor respective values inserted.  odds ratio information always centered two vertical lines. Hence looks nice gap two chosen values (0.099 0.198) large enough. smoothing line crosses inserted text, can correct adjusting or_yloc. argument sets y-location inserted odds ratio information. Depending digits chosen values (3), might also need adjust x-axis location two values interfere vertical line. Let’s inserting another odds ratio result plot. time simply take already produced plot input insert_or() use new odds ratio result:  Using rect = TRUE, can additionally highlight certain odds ratio intervals. Aesthetics like opacity color fully customizable.
code: plot_object <- plot_gam(fit_gam, pred = "x2", title = "Predictor 'x2'") or_object <- or_gam(   data = data_gam, model = fit_gam,   pred = "x2", values = c(0.099, 0.198) )  plot <- insert_or(plot_object, or_object,   or_yloc = 3,   values_xloc = 0.05, arrow_length = 0.02,   arrow_col = "red" ) plot +   theme_minimal() or_object2 <- or_gam(   data = data_gam, model = fit_gam,   pred = "x2", values = c(0.4, 0.6) )  insert_or(plot, or_object2,   or_yloc = 2.1, values_yloc = 2,   line_col = "green4", text_col = "black",   rect_col = "green4", rect_alpha = 0.2,   line_alpha = 1, line_type = "dashed",   arrow_xloc_r = 0.01, arrow_xloc_l = -0.01,   arrow_length = 0.02, rect = TRUE ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Getting Started
text: Fit model.
code: fit_glm <- glm(admit ~ gre + gpa + rank, data = data_glm, family = "binomial")

title: Getting Started
text: GLMs, odds ratio calculation simpler odds ratio changes correspond static predictor increases throughout complete value range predictor Hence, [or_glm()] takes increment steps predictor directly input via argument incr. avoid false predictor/value assignments, combinations need given named list. Odds ratios indicator variables computed automatically always refer base factor level. indicator predictor rank example dataset four levels. Subsequently, get three odds ratio outputs referring base factor level (: rank1) output can interpreted follows: “Given rank2 instead rank1 holding values constant results decrease odds 49.1% (1-0.509)”. can also set confident intervals GLM(M) models. resulting [data.frame] automatically adjust column names specified level.
code: or_glm(data = data_glm, model = fit_glm, incr = list(gre = 380, gpa = 5)) #>   predictor oddsratio ci_low (2.5) ci_high (97.5)          increment #> 1       gre     2.364        1.054          5.396                380 #> 2       gpa    55.712        2.229       1511.282                  5 #> 3     rank2     0.509        0.272          0.945 Indicator variable #> 4     rank3     0.262        0.132          0.512 Indicator variable #> 5     rank4     0.212        0.091          0.471 Indicator variable or_glm(   data = data_glm, model = fit_glm,   incr = list(gre = 380, gpa = 5), ci = 0.70 ) #>   predictor oddsratio ci_low (15) ci_high (85)          increment #> 1       gre     2.364       1.540        3.647                380 #> 2       gpa    55.712      10.084      314.933                  5 #> 3     rank2     0.509       0.366        0.706 Indicator variable #> 4     rank3     0.262       0.183        0.374 Indicator variable #> 5     rank4     0.212       0.136        0.325 Indicator variable

what: Odds Ratio Calculation for GAM(M)s & GLM(M)s
title: Odds Ratio Calculation for GAM(M)s & GLM(M)s
text: Functions calculation plotting odds ratios Generalized Additive (Mixed) Models Generalized Linear (Mixed) Models binomial response variable (.e. logistic regression models)

title: Odds Ratio Calculation for GAM(M)s & GLM(M)s

code: install.packages("oddsratio") remotes::install_github("pat-s/oddsratio")

what: Converts a fitted GAM model into a tidy data frame — gam_to_df
title: Converts a fitted GAM model into a tidy data frame — gam_to_df
text: function converts fitted GAM model tidy data frame

title: Converts a fitted GAM model into a tidy data frame — gam_to_df
code: gam_to_df(model = NULL, pred = NULL)

title: Converts a fitted GAM model into a tidy data frame — gam_to_df
text: model fitted GAM(M). pred Predictor name calculate odds ratio.

title: Converts a fitted GAM model into a tidy data frame — gam_to_df
text: able plot smoothing function GAM using ggplot2, preprocessing needed coming raw fitted GAM model output. Used plot_gam().

title: Converts a fitted GAM model into a tidy data frame — gam_to_df
code: # load data (Source: ?mgcv::gam) library(mgcv) #> Loading required package: nlme #> This is mgcv 1.9-3. For overview type 'help("mgcv-package")'. n <- 200 sig <- 2 dat <- gamSim(1, n = n, scale = sig, verbose = FALSE) dat$x4 <- as.factor(c(   rep("A", 50), rep("B", 50), rep("C", 50),   rep("D", 50) )) fit_gam <- gam(y ~ s(x0) + s(I(x1^2)) + s(x2) +   offset(x3) + x4, data = dat) # fit model  tmp <- gam_to_df(fit_gam, "x2")

what: Insert odds ratios of GAM(M)s into smoothing function — insert_or
title: Insert odds ratios of GAM(M)s into smoothing function — insert_or
text: function inserts calculated odds ratios GAM(M)s plot GAM(M) smoothing function.

title: Insert odds ratios of GAM(M)s into smoothing function — insert_or
code: insert_or(   plot_object = NULL,   or_object = NULL,   line_col = "red",   line_size = 1.2,   line_type = "solid",   line_alpha = 1,   text_alpha = 1,   text_size = 4,   text_col = "black",   rect_alpha = 0.5,   rect_col = NULL,   rect = FALSE,   arrow = TRUE,   values = TRUE,   values_yloc = 0,   values_xloc = NULL,   or_yloc = 0,   arrow_length = NULL,   arrow_yloc = NULL,   arrow_col = NULL,   arrow_xloc_r = NULL,   arrow_xloc_l = NULL )

title: Insert odds ratios of GAM(M)s into smoothing function — insert_or
text: plot_object ggplot object plot_gam(). or_object data.frame returned or_gam(). line_col, line_alpha, line_type, line_size Aesthetics vertical lines. text_col, text_alpha, text_size Aesthetics inserted values. rect_col, rect_alpha Aesthetics shaded rectangle. rect Whether print shaded rectangle vertical lines. arrow Whether print arrows inserted values. values Whether print predictor value information nearby inserted vertical lines. values_xloc x-axis location/shift values relative vertical line. Default 2\% x-axis range. or_yloc, values_yloc Specifies y-location inserted odds ratio values. Relative plotted y-axis range. positive (negative) value place text higher (lower). arrow_xloc_r, arrow_xloc_l, arrow_yloc, arrow_length, arrow_col Axis placement options inserted arrows. Relative respective axis ranges.

title: Insert odds ratios of GAM(M)s into smoothing function — insert_or
text: ggplot2::ggplot

title: Insert odds ratios of GAM(M)s into smoothing function — insert_or
text: idea behind function add calculated odds ratios fitted GAM models (or_gam()) plot showing smooth function (plot_gam) chosen predictor odds ratio calculated . Multiple insertions can made iterative calling function (see examples). Right now function accepts inputs or_gam() objects slice = FALSE. want insert multiple odds ratio values, call function multiple times.

title: Insert odds ratios of GAM(M)s into smoothing function — insert_or
code: library(oddsratio) library(mgcv) fit_gam <- gam(y ~ s(x0) + s(I(x1^2)) + s(x2) +   offset(x3) + x4, data = data_gam) # fit model  # create input objects (plot + odds ratios) plot_object <- plot_gam(fit_gam, pred = "x2", title = "Predictor 'x2'") or_object1 <- or_gam(   data = data_gam, model = fit_gam,   pred = "x2", values = c(0.099, 0.198) )  # insert first odds ratios to plot plot_object <- insert_or(plot_object, or_object1,   or_yloc = 3,   values_xloc = 0.04, line_size = 0.5,   line_type = "dotdash", text_size = 6,   values_yloc = 0.5, arrow_col = "red" )  # calculate second odds ratio or_object2 <- or_gam(   data = data_gam, model = fit_gam, pred = "x2",   values = c(0.4, 0.6) )  # add or_object2 into plot insert_or(plot_object, or_object2,   or_yloc = 2.1, values_yloc = 2,   line_col = "green4", text_col = "black",   rect_col = "green4", rect_alpha = 0.2,   line_alpha = 1, line_type = "dashed",   arrow_xloc_r = 0.01, arrow_xloc_l = -0.01,   arrow_length = 0.01, rect = TRUE )

what: Suppress plotting output of plot function — no_plot
title: Suppress plotting output of plot function — no_plot
text: function suppresses plotting output plot function

title: Suppress plotting output of plot function — no_plot
code: no_plot(model = NULL)

title: Suppress plotting output of plot function — no_plot
text: model fitted GAM(M).

title: Suppress plotting output of plot function — no_plot
text: prevent unwanted plot printing plot function call desire work returned information plot. Used plot_gam().

title: Suppress plotting output of plot function — no_plot
code: # load data (Source: ?mgcv::gam) library(mgcv) n <- 200 sig <- 2 dat <- gamSim(1, n = n, scale = sig, verbose = FALSE) dat$x4 <- as.factor(c(   rep("A", 50), rep("B", 50), rep("C", 50),   rep("D", 50) )) fit_gam <- gam(y ~ s(x0) + s(I(x1^2)) + s(x2) +   offset(x3) + x4, data = dat) # fit model  tmp <- plot(fit_gam, pages = 1) # plot output  tmp <- no_plot(fit_gam) # no plot output

what: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Additive (Mixed) Models — or_gam
title: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Additive (Mixed) Models — or_gam
text: function calculates odds ratio(s) specific increment steps GAM(M) models. Odds ratios can also calculated continuous (percentage) increment steps across whole predictor distribution using slice = TRUE.

title: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Additive (Mixed) Models — or_gam
code: or_gam(   data = NULL,   model = NULL,   pred = NULL,   values = NULL,   percentage = NULL,   slice = FALSE,   ci = NULL )

title: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Additive (Mixed) Models — or_gam
text: data data used model fitting. model fitted GAM(M). pred Predictor name calculate odds ratio. values Numeric vector length two. Predictor values estimate odds ratio . Function written use first provided value "lower" one, .e. calculating odds ratio 'value1 value2'. used slice = FALSE. percentage Percentage number split predictor distribution . value 10 split predictor distribution 10\ needed slice = TRUE. slice Whether calculate odds ratios fixed increment steps whole predictor distribution. See percentage setting increment values. ci Currently fixed 95\ Currently supported functions: mgcv::gam, mgcv::gamm, gam::gam. mgcv::gamm, model input or_gam needs gam output (e.g. fit_gam$gam).

title: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Additive (Mixed) Models — or_gam
text: data.frame () eight columns. perc1 perc2 returned slice = TRUE: predictor Predictor name value1 First value odds ratio calculation value2 Second value odds ratio calculation perc1 Percentage value value1 perc2 Percentage value value2 oddsratio Calculated odds ratio(s) ci_low Lower (2.5%) confident interval odds ratio ci_high Higher (97.5%) confident interval odds ratio

title: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Additive (Mixed) Models — or_gam
code: library(oddsratio) library(mgcv) fit_gam <- gam(y ~ s(x0) + s(I(x1^2)) + s(x2) +   offset(x3) + x4, data = data_gam) # fit model  # Calculate OR for specific increment step of continuous variable or_gam(   data = data_gam, model = fit_gam, pred = "x2",   values = c(0.099, 0.198) ) #>   predictor value1 value2 oddsratio CI_low (2.5%) CI_high (97.5%) #> 1        x2  0.099  0.198  23.32353      23.30424        23.34283  ## Calculate OR for change of indicator variable or_gam(   data = data_gam, model = fit_gam, pred = "x4",   values = c("B", "D") ) #>   predictor value1 value2 oddsratio CI_low (2.5%) CI_high (97.5%) #> 1        x4      B      D 0.4744264     0.4976375        0.452298  ## Calculate ORs for percentage increments of predictor distribution ## (here: 20%) or_gam(   data = data_gam, model = fit_gam, pred = "x2",   percentage = 20, slice = TRUE ) #>   predictor value1 value2 perc1 perc2 oddsratio CI_low (2.5%) CI_high (97.5%) #> 1        x2  0.001  0.200     0    20   2510.77       1091.68         5774.53 #> 2        x2  0.200  0.400    20    40      0.03          0.03            0.03 #> 3        x2  0.400  0.599    40    60      0.58          0.56            0.60 #> 4        x2  0.599  0.799    60    80      0.06          0.06            0.06 #> 5        x2  0.799  0.998    80   100      0.41          0.75            0.22

what: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Linear (Mixed) Models — or_glm
title: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Linear (Mixed) Models — or_glm
text: function calculates odds ratio(s) specific increment steps GLMs.

title: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Linear (Mixed) Models — or_glm
code: or_glm(data, model, incr, ci = 0.95)

title: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Linear (Mixed) Models — or_glm
text: data data used model fitting. model fitted GLM(M). incr Increment values predictor given named list. ci confidence interval calculate. Must 0 1. Default 0.95

title: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Linear (Mixed) Models — or_glm
text: data frame five columns: predictor Predictor name(s) oddsratio Calculated odds ratio(s) ci_low Lower confident interval odds ratio ci_high Higher confident interval odds ratio increment Increment predictor(s)

title: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Linear (Mixed) Models — or_glm
text: ci_low ci_high calculated GLM models MASS::glmmPQL() return confident intervals due penalizing behavior. Currently supported functions: stats::glm,MASS::glmmPQL

title: Calculate Odds Ratios of Generalized Linear (Mixed) Models — or_glm
code: ## Example with glm() library(oddsratio) # load data (source: http://www.ats.ucla.edu/stat/r/dae/logit.htm) and # fit model fit_glm <- glm(admit ~ gre + gpa + rank,   data = data_glm,   family = "binomial" ) # fit model  # Calculate OR for specific increment step of continuous variable or_glm(data = data_glm, model = fit_glm, incr = list(gre = 380, gpa = 5)) #>   predictor oddsratio ci_low (2.5) ci_high (97.5)          increment #> 1       gre     2.364        1.054          5.396                380 #> 2       gpa    55.712        2.229       1511.282                  5 #> 3     rank2     0.509        0.272          0.945 Indicator variable #> 4     rank3     0.262        0.132          0.512 Indicator variable #> 5     rank4     0.212        0.091          0.471 Indicator variable  # Calculate OR and change the confidence interval level or_glm(   data = data_glm, model = fit_glm,   incr = list(gre = 380, gpa = 5), ci = .70 ) #>   predictor oddsratio ci_low (15) ci_high (85)          increment #> 1       gre     2.364       1.540        3.647                380 #> 2       gpa    55.712      10.084      314.933                  5 #> 3     rank2     0.509       0.366        0.706 Indicator variable #> 4     rank3     0.262       0.183        0.374 Indicator variable #> 5     rank4     0.212       0.136        0.325 Indicator variable  ## Example with MASS:glmmPQL() # load data library(MASS) data(bacteria) fit_glmmPQL <- glmmPQL(y ~ trt + week,   random = ~ 1 | ID,   family = binomial, data = bacteria,   verbose = FALSE )  # Apply function or_glm(data = bacteria, model = fit_glmmPQL, incr = list(week = 5)) #> Warning: No confident interval calculation possible for 'glmmPQL' models. #>   predictor oddsratio ci_low ci_high          increment #> 1   trtdrug     0.296     NA      NA Indicator variable #> 2  trtdrug+     0.454     NA      NA Indicator variable #> 3      week     0.485     NA      NA                  5

title: Plot GAM(M) Smoothing Function — plot_gam
text: Plots smoothing function GAM(M) predictors via ggplot2

title: Plot GAM(M) Smoothing Function — plot_gam
code: plot_gam(   model = NULL,   pred = NULL,   col_line = "blue",   ci_line_col = "black",   ci_line_type = "dashed",   ci_fill = "grey",   ci_alpha = 0.4,   ci_line_size = 0.8,   sm_fun_size = 1.1,   title = NULL,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   limits_y = NULL,   breaks_y = NULL )

title: Plot GAM(M) Smoothing Function — plot_gam
text: model fitted model class gam. pred Predictor name. col_line Smoothing function line color. ci_line_col Confident interval line color. ci_line_type Linetype confidence interval. ci_fill Fill color area smoothing function confidence interval lines. ci_alpha Opacity value confidence interval. ci_line_size, sm_fun_size Line sizes. title Plot title. xlab x-axis title. ylab y-axis title. limits_y y-axis limits. breaks_y y-axis breaks. Values handed seq call, e.g. seq(-6, 6, 2).

title: Plot GAM(M) Smoothing Function — plot_gam
code: library(oddsratio) library(mgcv) fit_gam <- mgcv::gam(y ~ s(x0) + s(I(x1^2)) + s(x2) + offset(x3) + x4,   data = data_gam )  plot_gam(fit_gam, pred = "x2", title = "Predictor 'x2'")
